page.title: 02THE LANDSCAPE OF WEST CAMBS.
page.content:
Looking across the area, one sees a slightly-undulating expanse of arable farmland, with large fields of cereal crops, broken by the occasional hedge and a few small patches of grass and woodland. Much of the land is accessible only on foot or over rough farm tracks and bridleways.
The area is low-lying, reaching only seventy-seven metres above sea level at Blackwell Manor Farm in the South-West and sloping gently down to thirty metres in the North-East. The geology consists of Oxford Clay, with deposits of glacial Boulder Clay on higher land in the South-West.
Three small streams drain the area, flowing in a north-easterly direction to join Alconbury Brook, a tributary of the Great Ouse.
